app.title: Shall We Get Married?
app.subtitle: An in-depth conversation about intimacy and life perspectives

startScreen.title: Shall We Get Married?
description: 5 intimate themes, 24 heartfelt question cards, guiding you to explore each other's values, wishes, and visions for the future.
There are no standard answers here, only moments of resonance unique to you. Are you ready to embark on a journey toward deeper understanding and intimacy?

results.title: You've reached the end
results.subtitle: But love is just beginning from here

Values.name: Values
Values.description: Your core values and attitude toward life

Life Planning.name: Life Planning
Life Planning.description: Your plans and goals for the future

Money Attitude.name: Money Attitude
Money Attitude.description: Your attitude toward money and spending

Family Views.name: Family Views
Family Views.description: Your views on family relationships and responsibilities

Relationship Views.name: Relationship Views
Relationship Views.description: How you express and handle emotions

questions.question: If one day you find out your child is gay, what would your attitude be?

options.A: Respect and bless them, I just hope they are happy
options.B: Not sure what to do, need some time to process
options.C: Hard to accept

questions.question: If you have children, what do you think is the ideal educational path?

options.A: Happy education: Respect the child's nature and curiosity. They don't need to be the best, but should be the happiest.
options.B: Achievement-oriented: Education shouldn't just go with the flow. It's okay to sacrifice some short-term childhood happiness for long-term development. That's true responsibility.
options.C: Haven't thought about it

questions.question: Do you agree that people should do age-appropriate things at each stage of life?

options.A: Agree, life has different tasks and goals at each stage
options.B: Disagree, there isn't just one script for life
options.C: No particular opinion

questions.question: Which of the following statements best matches your view on life paths and destiny?

options.A: Life trajectory is mostly determined by environment and social structure; what we can control is limited
options.B: The world is full of possibilities; everyone can create their own future through determination and effort
options.C: Instead of worrying about changing fate, it's better to focus on experiencing the present

questions.question: In five years, do you think you can live a better life through your own efforts?

options.A: I believe I definitely can
options.B: Hard to say, depends on luck and opportunities
options.C: If I still have a job in five years, that's good enough

questions.question: If you discuss future family retirement plans with your partner, how much money do you think counts as financial freedom?

options.A: Never stop striving: I hope to keep creating value; financial freedom isn't the ultimate goal
options.B: Safety first: Need enough assets and passive income to handle inflation, medical risks, etc. Security is important
options.C: Minimalism: Enough for the family's basic living, medical, and education needs. The less desire, the more freedom
options.D: Live in the moment: Spend what you earn, financial freedom isn't realistic

questions.question: If you are suddenly laid off, what would you do?

options.A: Take a short break and immediately start looking for the next job
options.B: Prepare to look for a stable government job or similar, aiming for security
options.C: Travel the world and pursue freedom, like becoming a digital nomad or blogger
options.D: It's a chance from fate! Time to switch to what I've always wanted to do
options.E: Don't want to work hard anymore

questions.question: Which of the following job offers is more attractive to you?

options.A: A stable position at a large company, with mid-to-high income but limited growth
options.B: A startup project, low income in the short term but you believe in its future potential
options.C: A jack-of-all-trades role at a small company, stressful but you can learn a lot

questions.question: One day, your partner suggests moving to another country together. What is your first reaction?

options.A: Excited, I've always wanted to experience a different world
options.B: Resistant, I don't want to easily give up my current life and job

questions.question: Your partner buys an expensive luxury item with their own money that you think is impractical. You would:

options.A: Support them, happiness is priceless
options.B: Don't really understand but respect their choice
options.C: Express your opinion reasonably and advise them not to fall into consumerism

questions.question: Which attitude toward saving money is closest to yours?

options.A: Very important, life is unpredictable
options.B: Save moderately, but not so much that it affects quality of life
options.C: Money is for life experiences; saving for the sake of saving is meaningless

questions.question: If you and your partner have a shared bank account, you would prefer:

options.A: Each contributes half
options.B: Whoever earns more contributes more
options.C: Whoever contributes less to household work (like chores or childcare) should contribute more financially
options.D: No need for a shared account, earn and spend separately

questions.question: What is your attitude toward prenuptial agreements?

options.A: Necessary, just in case. Talking about money doesn't hurt feelings
options.B: Hurts feelings, thinking about divorce before marriage
options.C: Never thought about it

questions.question: After marriage, how close do you want to live to both sets of parents?

options.A: Live nearby for convenience and care
options.B: Live far away to maintain independent space
options.C: Each lives their own life, hope to keep relative independence

questions.question: If you and your partner are from different hometowns, what is your ideal Chinese New Year arrangement after marriage?

options.A: Follow my partner's plan, my family is flexible
options.B: Try to go to my home, my family values these traditions
options.C: Take turns, this year at your home, next year at mine
options.D: Each goes to their own home
options.E: No need to go home, both families can travel together

questions.question: If your parents keep urging you to break up, what would you do?

options.A: Don't tell my partner, but since my parents keep saying it, I'll consider if they have a point
options.B: Tell my partner, discuss the issues, and try to solve them together
options.C: Ignore outside voices, even parents may not understand the real situation

questions.question: After getting together, what is your ideal way to divide household chores?

options.A: As evenly as possible (e.g., do together or take turns) to reduce inequality
options.B: Divide by expertise or preference (e.g., one cooks, the other washes dishes)
options.C: Whoever contributes more financially can do less housework
options.D: Hire help, try not to do it ourselves

questions.question: You accidentally find out your partner secretly watches borderline/risqu√© videos. What would you do?

options.A: Strongly condemn and ask them to unfollow
options.B: Unhappy, but won't ask them to unfollow
options.C: Doesn't matter, just pretend I didn't see
options.D: Tell them there's no need to be sneaky, they can watch openly

questions.question: What do you think about the sense of ritual on anniversaries?

options.A: Essential, without it the relationship will wither
options.B: I don't care, but if my partner needs it, I'll cooperate
options.C: Don't like it, what's important is the little things in daily life

questions.question: Do you think physical attraction is important in a long-term intimate relationship?

options.A: Very important, sexual attraction is the cornerstone of a high-quality relationship
options.B: Important, but not the only standard. Emotional and spiritual connection matter more
options.C: Not very important, intimacy can go beyond physical attraction

questions.question: If you are in a stable relationship but develop a clear and strong crush on someone else, what would you do?

options.A: Loyalty first: Since I've committed to my partner, I should cut off feelings and avoid temptation
options.B: Rebuild relationship: Liking someone else means there's no love left for my current partner, so I should responsibly choose the new person
options.C: Be honest: Tell my partner about my feelings, share my emotional state, the most important thing is not to hide
options.D: Rational evaluation: Analyze why I have a crush, whether it reflects something missing in the relationship, and weigh whether to continue

questions.question: You've never been apart for long since being together, but now your partner tells you they need to go on a business trip for a month. What is your natural reaction?

options.A: Pretty sad, living alone is lonely
options.B: Doesn't matter, as long as we keep in touch
options.C: Great, finally some alone time

questions.question: When making personal decisions in a relationship, you tend to:

options.A: Hope to get my partner's support and approval as much as possible
options.B: Respect their opinion, but ultimately decide for myself
options.C: Basically don't need their opinion

questions.question: If your partner gets a job opportunity in another city and decides to go, what would you do?

options.A: Start looking for a job there and try to go together
options.B: Can do long-distance for now, see what happens later
options.C: As long as I earn significantly more, try to persuade them to stay
options.D: Can't do long-distance at all, need to reconsider the relationship
